data.title: How the Nazis Messed Up Spanish Clocks
data.meta_description: They say you shouldn’t write an email while angry; you’ll inevitably end up saying things you will come to regret. Does the same apply to Medium posts? I don’t know. But we’re about to find out…
data.text:
They say you shouldn’t write an email while angry; you’ll inevitably end up saying things you will come to regret. Does the same apply to Medium posts? I don’t know. But we’re about to find out. Because I’m angry. Why am I angry? Well, Spain (and the rest of Europe) moves its clocks forward this coming weekend. What’s the big deal about that? It means that the sun won’t be rising until after 8:30am here in “sunny” Seville. In March! This isn’t the dead of winter. It’s the start of spring! So why will I (and the rest of the Spanish workforce) be waking up and starting our days in the pitch black? Well, it’s the Nazis’ fault. No, seriously.

Before we get to the Nazis, let’s establish some facts: Spain is in the wrong timezone. It’s as simple as that. Just look at a map. Geographically speaking, Spain should follow Western European Time a.k.a Greenwich Mean Time (UTC ± 0:00) along with the likes of Portugal, the United Kingdom, and Ireland; all countries that share a similar longitude on the western edge of Europe. But instead, Spain follows Central European Time (UTC +1:00). This puts Spain as the most westward European country to follow this timezone and in the same timezone as, for example, Białystok, Poland–a city that is some 31 degrees of longitude away…
